text: Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time? Doctor: Yeah me and if people live around her they see me. If you know have a relationship with Dr. F__ and that’s closer. Family Member: I would like to keep you both though because I think you know it would be more convenient to be close to home and I know they have state-of-the-art equipment there because I’ve already talked to the manager of the cancer center and um and then to still be coming here. text: Family Member: And basically that’s what we are doing. He’s mostly had chicken, fish, uh. Now I occasionally I prepare, cook. Is pork okay? Doctor: Uh hum. Just lean cuts. Doctor: He can have beef, a little lean, just in moderation, not the fatty kind. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. text: Patient: We’re good. (Door closes) Doctor: Everybody but me has come into the room. Nice to see you. You’re making me think today. Patient: Well, that’s good. text: Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now. Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment.

text: Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin. Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
